Award.AwardTitle: Spectroscopy and Photodissociation Dynamics Imaging of C-C and C-H Bond Activation by Transition Metal and Metal Oxide Cations
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Experimental Physical Chemistry Program of the Division of Chemistry supports the research of Professor Ricardo Metz and his students at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst. Professor Metz will study the spectroscopy and photodissociation dynamics of the reactants and intermediates of reactions in which C-C and C-H bonds are activated by transition metal and metal oxide cations. As a reaction proceeds from reactants to products, it forms several intermediates (e.g., entrance channel complexes, insertion intermediates, and exit channel complexes). By studying the structure and bonding of these intermediates, Metz and his students will be able to characterize the detailed mechanism for the reaction. Vibrational spectroscopy will be used to study bonding in the ground electronic states of the ions. A novel photofragment imaging instrument will be constructed to study ion photodissociation dynamics following electronic excitation, measuring kinetic energy release and fragment anisotropy. This will determine precise bond strengths and is a detailed probe of excited state dynamics and the couplings between excited electronic states. Reactions to be studied include the conversion of methane to larger hydrocarbons by metal atoms and clusters and methane to methanol and benzene to phenol conversion by metal oxides. Photoionization studies of neutral metal oxides and metal carbenes carried out at the Advanced Light Source, Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory, will measure ionization energies and neutral bond strengths. Extensive electronic structure calculations will complement the experiments.

Improved catalysts are needed to make optimal use of limited energy resources, and fundamental studies of C-H and C-C bond activation aid in this effort by expanding our understanding of the mechanisms of metal-based catalysis. The project also provides graduate students and postdoctoral researchers with extensive training in experimental and computational physical chemistry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this work, supported by the Experimental Physical Chemistry Program of the Division of Chemistry, Professor Ricardo Metz, his graduate and undergraduate students and a postdoctoral associate studied the spectroscopy and photodissociation dynamics of the reactants and intermediates of reactions in which C-C and C-H bonds are activated by transition metal and metal oxide cations. As a reaction proceeds from reactants to products, it forms several intermediates (such as entrance channel complexes, insertion intermediates, and exit channel complexes). By studying the structure and bonding of these intermediates, they were be able to characterize the detailed mechanism for the conversion of methane to methanol and benzene to phenol by iron oxide and cobalt oxide cations. They also studied complexes of iron, cobalt and nickel cations with methane, determining how binding to the metal weakens the C-H bonds; the weakening is most pronounced for cobalt, and decreases as additional methane molecules are added. Vibrational spectroscopy was used to study bonding in the ground electronic states of the ions. Spectra were measured by combining mass spectrometric isolation of parent ions, photodissociation using one or more tunable lasers, and mass spectrometric detection of fragment ions.  In addition, electronic spectroscopy studies examined the interaction between metal ions and water, and how this is affected by the nature of the metal, and by its electron occupancy. Ions with partially full 3d orbitals and an empty 4s orbital bind water more strongly than those with an electron in the 4s orbital. Photoionization studies carried out at the Advanced Light Source, Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory measured ionization energies of intermediates and products of the reaction of platinum atom with methane. As a result, the relative energies of the key H-Pt-CH3 insertion intermediate, and of the overall reaction to form platinum carbene and hydrogen, were determined. Extensive electronic structure calculations complement all of the experiments, and indicated that, by including spin-orbit corrections, standard density functionals can accurately reproduce the measured energetics for the platinum complexes.

Improved catalysts are needed to make optimal use of limited energy resources, and fundamental studies of C-H and C-C bond activation aid in this effort by expanding our understanding of the mechanisms of metal-based catalysis. The project also provided undergraduate and graduate students and a postdoctoral researcher with extensive training in experimental and computational physical chemistry.
